channel.title: GENRE: ___Hip-Hop___
channel.description:
This topic is for general discussion about <big>Hip-Hop</big>
Chat with others who like this genre about:
- New or Favorite tracks and artists - Music making techniques - Samples / instruments - origins / definition of the genre
Please paste your finished Hip-Hop tracks in the #Tracks category so all the tracks are in one location, but you can post a link to that topic from here if you want.

item.title: GENRE: ___Hip-Hop___
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
Saw this over on the AudioBus forum, find it incredibly inspiring (I’m not a hip-hop head at all, though lord knows I enjoy a good broken beat :))

https://www.youtube.com/embed/lC0JFXw_6kQ

These “watch as the artist builds a track up” videos (ala Against the Clock style) are great, really digging on these lately to see the process.

item.title: GENRE: ___Hip-Hop___
item.dc:creator: therealejoc
item.description:
I never said that. The 70s and 80s had rap and hip hop but it wasn’t as popular. It grew way more significantly in the late 80s & early 90s. Also, I don’t know everything so if I get something wrong just lemme know, preferably ina constructive way :).

item.description:
Is this speaking of hip hop as in rap or the total overarching genre? Because rapping is what makes hip hop, hip hop. Without it it would just be boring. (Not saying all
Hip hop songs are rap just saying that the origins lie within greats such as biggie and pac. And mc hammer .

item.title: GENRE: ___Hip-Hop___
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
TheRealJFalc:

how does one exactly hop the hip then, and incorporate the “break beats” into the music?

As always, start with listening – a lot.
Listen to the artists and tracks that inspired you to give hip-hop a try – or that sit closest to the type of hip-hop sound you’d like to try.

Then ask for help on details.

Read full topic

item.title: GENRE: ___Hip-Hop___

item.description:

Deciding which friends to go clubbing with was a decision between this…

or this…

Of course, I was more into electro - so I went like this…

item.title: GENRE: ___Hip-Hop___
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
blakkaz:

‘Nu Skool’ breaks predate both EDM and Dubstep, so perhaps it was the other way around?

Yeah, didn’t mean to suggest that the techniques derive from EDM and DS, just that the electronic production attitude is shared.

I think it has as much to do with the evolution of DAWs and production ‘sounds’ as a genre-to-genre thing.

 

pretty even split between hardcore/breakbeat romantics and hip-hop turntablists.

That’s interesting. In terms of ‘coming from’, I’d say the influence on the contemporary sound — to my ears — is spiritually more synthetic than anything I’d associate with essential Hip-Hop.

Read full topic

item.title: GENRE: ___Hip-Hop___
item.dc:creator: blakkaz
item.description:
A quality post.

I agree for the most part, but would like to add -

akabillposters:

…mixed with some EDM and Dubstep composition and production touches.

‘Nu Skool’ breaks predate both EDM and Dubstep, so perhaps it was the other way around?

akabillposters:

From the sound of it, Breakbeat artists tend to come mostly via the Electronic/EDM influence, rather than the Hip-Hop influence.

I was fortunate enough to work with many of the prominent breakbeat artists during it’s heyday and I’d say there was a pretty even split between hardcore/breakbeat romantics and hip-hop turntablists.

Read full topic

item.title: GENRE: ___Hip-Hop___
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Historically, breakbeat… (click for more details)

 

As I see it (hear it), contemporary breakbeat is spiritually quite close to Big Beat.

Akin to a descendent of The Chemical Brothers’ heavier stuff mixed with some EDM and Dubstep composition and production touches. Certainly, energy-wise, Breakbeat is closer to EDM and Dubstep.

From the sound of it, Breakbeat artists tend to come mostly via the Electronic/EDM influence, rather than the Hip-Hop influence.

 
Hip-Hop is the precursor to Rap and still represents the ‘softer’ side of that genre (though the two are still often used synonymously).

Bands that still represent the Hip-Hop vibe would be Tribe Called Quest, through mainstream artists like Snoop Dogg, 50 Cent, through to Kendrick Lamar and even Cardi B.

…spinning off into things like Trap.

…though the Hip-Hop influence has spread and touched pretty much every genre, even tweeny pop like Ed Sheeran and Taylor Swift.

Read full topic
